data.title: Hours after closing all VS Code windows, the process still eats ~18% CPU
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Close all VS Code windows.
2. Open Task manager
3. See this:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1550920/24614978/38d01e9a-188d-11e7-9686-f4437f356995.png)

Obviously, I'm not sure if this is deterministic, related to some extension I have installed or to something in any of the folders I had open, so I guess the first steps will be to help me narrow down what is actually running. If there are any tricks I need to pull to extract a log file from somewhere, let me know.

data.title: debug javascript , Object.defineProperty have a problem
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. debug javascript
2.when I use Object.definProperty to add property to an object, the property was not added

``` javascript
var temp = {
	age: 18
};

Object.defineProperty(temp, 'name', {
	value: 'Bob',
	configurable: false,
	writable: false,
	enumerable: false
});

console.log(temp);  // { age: 18 }
```
![ue8 v2u 3o5vora1n4w5tgf](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8167270/24612061/bc583080-18b6-11e7-8a60-ebdd981ea759.png)

data.title: VSC freezes X on verifying git SSH fingerprint

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.12.0 - Commit 5e5e9e3bb56a3182e58ad097e107966633643253
- OS Version:Arch Linux

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  Open VSC
2. File > Open Folder > Open
3. Crash. Seems to happen with git projects only?

This started happening out of the blue, older or newest VSC git version don't make a difference. I was on the same - working version, and after OS update it started freezing X. I can only move my cursor afterwards. Switching to a different TTY and killing VSC does not make a difference, I have to restart X.

I did a clean install of the OS and it still happened.

I can't reproduce this on my desktop with nvidia GPU, only laptop with integrated intel(and old AMD card, which is possibly not working).

I attached a folder that causes it.

[MCModUpdater.zip](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/890053/MCModUpdater.zip)

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Having following:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11234139/24609310/a34353ae-187a-11e7-89ec-faf2fa09fe69.png)
2. See that the unindention of ` $node instanceof Node\Expr\FuncCall` won't be marked.

code:
before:
```php
} else if
            (
                    $node instanceof Node\Expr\FuncCall
                &&  $node->name instanceof Node\Name
                &&  (string)$node->name === 'define'
                &&  isset($node->args[0])
                &&  $node->args[0]->value instanceof Node\Scalar\String_
            ) {
```
after:
```php
 } else if (
                $node instanceof Node\Expr\FuncCall
                &&  $node->name instanceof Node\Name
                &&  (string)$node->name === 'define'
                &&  isset($node->args[0])
                &&  $node->args[0]->value instanceof Node\Scalar\String_
            ) {
```

data.title: [themes] simpler way to create and edit themes
data.body:
Newbie alert:  I have been programming for 40+ years and used many different code editors, but I am relatively new to VSCode.

I do not like any of the standard colour themes so I thought I would edit an existing theme or define a new one of my own.  You can do this easily in many other code editors.

However, the documentation implies that all I can do is trawl through hundreds of themes for other editors (TextMate or Sublime Text) and convert them...  Yes, I have tried searching more widely, on StackOverflow and elsewhere. It seems to be a common issue for VSCode users.

Surely, it should be possible to edit a theme in much the same way that settings are handled?  The theme should be specified ultimately with one or more (per language) JSON files that the user can edit or overlay.  Something somewhere in VSCode is doing the equivalent of parsing the text, tagging the components and looking up the right colour in a map.  That map could be loaded as a JSON file.


- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: MacOS 10.12.4

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Try to edit or create a theme!

data.title: Font changes if editor contains a special unicode code point

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Type an arbitrary text containing the unicode symbol '(̈́'. Python claims the encoding to be '\xcd\x84', but I cannot find this code point in unicode.

Using this code point results in the following layout for the text:

`print d.getVar(̈́'VERSION',True)`

The fixed spaced font changes into a proportional font for that line

![font_error](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/13770135/24604918/1a9e5cbe-1867-11e7-90bc-067e2a0a642c.png)

data.title: Small fix for Italian "Go To Bracket" command
data.body: "Go To Bracket" has been translated in Italian with "Vai alla parentesi quadra"; in Italian the "parentesi quadra" is literally the square bracket, while the English command (and its effective usage) is about every kind of bracket. So the "quadra" ("square") has no sense in the command description.

data.title: Make "files to include" box multi-line.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Working with a game engine can entail being interested in a whole lot of different file types.. :)

![filestoinclude gif](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1578924/24602679/2d8f22c6-185e-11e7-86e7-71ac7f5dfd05.gif)

Here's my current filter:
*.cpp, *.h, *.inl, *.js, *.lua, *.cs, *.html, *.flow_node_definitions, *.txt, *.material, *.shader_source, *.shader_node, *.flow, *.rb, *.cmake, *.plugin, *.particles, *.shader_source, *.shader_node, *.material

It's becoming hard to know what's in it. In fact, I just noticed that I've included the shader file types twice!

This request is slightly related to this issue: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/20547

* V8 (53 => 56)
* Chrome (53 => 56)
* node.js (6.5.0 => 7.4.0 [breaking changes](https://github.com/nodejs/node/wiki/Breaking-changes-between-v6-and-v7))
* libuv (1.9.1 => 1.10.1)

![panel-red](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/900690/24599115/ffbb50fe-184e-11e7-801a-4aa21dc93077.gif)

data.title: Ugly flicker in "opened editors" view when preview is enabled
data.body:
Steps to Reproduce:

1. set `"workbench.editor.enablePreview": true`
2. start to open an pin editors
3. start to open new groups and continue

=> there is ugly flicker where the element first seems to show to the top and then moves down
=> seems to be introduced by https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/commit/698b667397163221f465bf5dea9e8b77c5ced4d2

![panel-red](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/900690/24598671/e7e01b24-184c-11e7-9848-466882b59773.gif)

@isidorn that [whole code for updating](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/files/browser/views/openEditorsView.ts#L184) seems overly complicated and there seems to be many non structural events followed by one structural at almost the same time. Why don't you just always run through the delayer and refresh the groups as needed? Looking at the code you now seem to refresh groups on each event (if non structural) and then in the structural branch you end up refreshing the same group in some cases. Hard to understand that logic...

data.title: Adopt menu service and commands for save conflict actions (for #23420)
Focus returned to search bar after requesting next search result
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: MacOS Sierra 10.12.2 (16C67)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. cmd+shift+f
2. enter search term 
3. enter
4. F4 to go to result

Focus is given to search field instead of result in editor, meaning that user must repeatedly revisit the mouse when editing files. I think this is a recent regression.

data.title: debug with electron, breakpoints halt the program
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: ubuntu 16.04
- electron version: 1.6.2

my `launch.json` looks like this:

```json
{
  "version": "0.2.0",
  "configurations": [
    {
      "name": "Debug Main Process",
      "type": "node",
      "request": "launch",
      "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
      "runtimeExecutable": "${workspaceRoot}/node_modules/.bin/electron",
      "windows": {
        "runtimeExecutable": "${workspaceRoot}/node_modules/.bin/electron.cmd"
      },
      "program": "${workspaceRoot}/main.js"
    }
  ]
}
```

when vscode hits a breakpoint, it does not show the debug view. for example, the little yellow arrow does not show up at the breakpoint. The program just halts there.

Regards

data.title: Cannot find Module gc-signals or keymapping when trying to run from source
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 (Version 1607)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Get a fresh version and build with the npm.bat script (`./scripts/npm.bat run watch`)
2. Try to run the build, which should fail with:

- `Error: Cannot find module './build/Release/keymapping`
- `Error: Cannot find module '../build/Release/gcsignals'`

I then used the npm.bat file to install gc-signals and native-keymap, which I saw from the node modules folder, and now it's at least running correctly. I followed the instructions as well as I could. Could this be an issue with using virtualenv to have Python 2.7?
